abstract.para: This document describes our game design philosophy, our goals, and the differences between us and other mmorpgs. It is the project's basic and briefest management document.
If you have any questions, feel free to ask them at project’s forum or via e-mail input@ireon.org.

sect1.title: What do we do
sect1.para: Our primary goal is to develop a multiplayer online three-dimensional RPG, a client-server persistent virtual world.
The game is to be played through the Internet. The virtual allocated server will be rented for the game. Playing the game will be free of charge for all users.
Ireon is an open source software, full source code is going to be available through GPL license.

sect2.title: The platform
sect2.para: The game is going to be developed for the PC platform. Development for other platforms currently is not planned. Developers will support the client for Windows OS, and server for FreeBSD. Developers will not support any other systems, but will help anyone who's willing to do it.

Hardware requirements for client and server parts will be described later in the Software Requirements Specification. Requirements should be relatively low to ensure wide accessibility (potential new developers included).

sect2.title: The audience
sect2.para: The game is designed for the players who are at least 14 years old. The game is intended for the English- and Russian-speaking markets (developers will support both English and Russian versions), that's why we are going to keep in mind opportunities for fairly simple localizations from the very beginning of development.

The world is designed for moderate and moderately hardcore players. Players should have basic knowledge of RPGs and online games. The game is not designed for hardcore lovers of any specific RPG systems or games.
Our increased attention to social and exploring parts of virtual worlds hopefully will attract some additional players from MUDs and browser-based online games.

sect2.title: Worlds out there
sect2.para: Some virtual worlds that share certain features with us:

listitem.para: World of Warcraft — a large-scale commercial world similar in concept and style (server-client model, three-dimensional world, real time play, fantasy setting, etc.)
Lineage II — in the same way as World of Warcraft
3sider — a browser-based game where players affect global world situation by their actions
Pentacore — a browsed-based game that has politics and territories under control of different factions

sect2.title: When is release
sect2.para: You can find information about planned playable release date in the Software Project Management Plan.

sect2.title: Our goals
sect2.para: Our goal is research and development (r&d) in game design, game programming and organization of distributed game development process. Certain project members may have other goals such as meeting new people or the world conquest :)

sect2.title: The metrics
sect2.para: We are going to consider the project successful if:

listitem.para: we have a detailed software requirements specification (two hundred pages excluding tables and so forth);
at least one game server is always online with at least 70-100 players online.

sect1.title: The problem
sect1.para: Nowadays the majority of large-scale client-server online RPGs are action-oriented worlds (Korean games are especially good examples of that). That is, they are designed mostly for those players who like fights, ratings, and tournaments.

On the other hand, surveys and studies (for example, see Nick Yee's Daedalus project) show that not all players are willing to have exactly this kind of life in a virtual world. Moreover, in our opinion a number of people who mostly want to socialize and interact greatly exceeds a number of action-lovers, but none of those people are taken into account in existing games.

There are some RPGs for those 'others'. For example A Tale in the Desert is designed mostly for explorer-type players and Second Life is designed mostly for socializers. And certainly there are hundreds of MUDs each giving innumerable options for roleplaying and socializing. But all these worlds can not be considered popular when seen against large commercial 'action' projects. In our POV, this is because of their flat learning curve (which is actually a bad thing opposite to the popular misapprehension), poor usability, and poor quality of service.

sect1.title: Our solution
sect1.para: The ultimate goal of our project is to combine highly varied and interesting gameplay from MUDs with human-friendly interface and easily understandable visuals of client-server RPGs. Our core aims are easy socializing and rich gameplay (where 'rich' means the roles of warrior and battle mage are not the only ones possible).

sect1.title: The differences between us and other projects
sect1.para: Our core difference from similar projects is gameplay based on needs of players, not dreams of developers. Our team is not a group of gamers that decided to develop 'a better World of Warcraft with more mobs'. In our work we are guided by studies and experience of leading experts in development of virtual worlds (you can find a list of recommended reading at our site). We pay special attention to usability and easy acquaintance of players with concepts of our world.
So, to sum up what do we have:

listitem.para: efficient management — we place high emphasis on development process, methodology, tools, documents, etc.;
highest possible openness (code included) that continually attracts new developers.

sect1.title: What to read next
sect1.para: If you are interested in project's management, next document you should read is probably the Software Project Management Plan.
If you want to learn about Ireon's game design, the place to begin is the Concept Document.
If you are not exactly sure what do you want to read next, our Documentaion Guide may help you to make up your mind.
